Award.AbstractNarration: The Indiana University REU Site will provide a research program for undergraduates during summers of 2009-2013, though support provided by NSF Directorates of Biological Sciences (BIO) and Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences (SBE). Ten students will be selected each year to participate in an intensive research program in an area of animal behavior. Students from biology, neuroscience, psychology and anthropology are welcome to apply. The goal is to increase students' likelihood to successfully enter a graduate school or a job in science. Students are matched with individual labs and have the opportunity to perform and complete their own research projects--including analyzing data, preparing findings in a poster format, and presenting at a concluding symposium. The program emphasizes an interdisciplinary environment beginning with introductory seminar meetings with a range of Animal Behavior faculty, and includes exposure to techniques of conducting genetic and neuroendocrine assays, collecting data in zoos, and making science accessible to the public. Students receive training in reasoning applied to the conduct of science with an emphasis on basic and applied animal behavior research, assistance in how to present research, strategies in taking GRE tests, and career options in science and education. Because the core emphasis is on the research experience, the scheduling of training events is designed to allow students to begin work in their host laboratories during the first week of the program. Students from institutions with limited research opportunities for research and those from groups under-represented in science are especially encouraged to apply. More information is available at http://www.indiana.edu/~animal/REU, or by contacting Linda Summers (812-855-9663 or cisab@indiana.edu) or the Program Director, Dr. Emilia Martins (812-855-1646 or emartins@indiana.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
During our last site award, we trained a total of 62 interns. In the process, we continually sought to improve the training we offer and extend training to additional stakeholders, building a broad community to support our efforts. Here, we describe the underlying goals, approaches, and outcomes of our efforts in five areas.

Conducting and disseminating cutting-edge behavioral research:  The Center for the Integrative Study of Animal behavior (CISAB) at Indiana University is recognized nationally as a premier organization for interdisciplinary animal behavior research. This gives the interns in our REU site program an unparalleled opportunity for immersion into cutting-edge approaches to animal behavior from mechanistic, evolutionary, and cognitive perspectives. Expectations are that interns will conduct an independent project to which they make an intellectual contribution, carry out and analyze experiments, and interpret the resulting data under the guidance of a mentor. Many projects that our interns have conducted in the last award period represent research that would not have otherwise been performed in their home labs, or the initiation of new collaborations. Interns present the results of their studies as a capstone within our program and are encouraged and assisted to present at additional meetings after the end of the program. As a result, many interns attend field-specific national meetings.

Career skills/ RCR training: In addition to performing original behavioral research, interns receive training in career-related skills as well as in the responsible conduct of research, both of which are crucial to success in STEM disciplines. A workshop series covers topics such as self-presentation, experimental design, proposal development and writing, reading scientific literature, and time management. Specific assignments give students the opportunity to receive feedback from mentors and critiques from peers. In collaboration with the Poynter Center for the Study of Ethics at Indiana University, students also receive training in topics including the ethics of animal use in research, scientific misconduct, student-mentor relationships, and peer review.

Building human resources in STEM: An important goal of our program is to increase participation in, and the diversity of, the STEM workforce by talented students. Our recruitment of 400-500 applicants per year allows us to offer training to students from a wide range of ethnic, economic, and educational backgrounds who do not have similar opportunities at their home institutions. In recent years, about 70% of our interns have from ethnic groups underrepresented in the sciences, 65% are women, and 53% are low income and/or first-generation college students. To increase the participation of these students in STEM careers, we focus on increasing familiarity with scientific careers. We do this in a range of ways, including holding graduate student and faculty panels on graduate school and academic careers, by acquainting interns with the process of applying to graduate school, helping them practice writing CVs and personal statements, and studying for and take the GRE. Later in the program, interns select faculty members for one-on-one meetings to reduce anxiety related to interacting with faculty, practice interview skills, and establish contacts in specific disciplines. Finally, students are encouraged and assisted in presenting their work at conferences after end of program, resulting in increased networking opportunities. In conjunction with these efforts, a high proportion of our interns report that they are more likely to continue in their scientific training after our program than before.
